questions.text: In the process of lymphocyte development, which of the following processes occurs in T cells but not in B cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Positive selection during development

 

Option C:

Positive Selection during Development: Positive selection ensures that developing T cells in the thymus cortex have TCRs that can appropriately recognize self-MHC molecules. This process does not occur in B cells; their selection processes, including "receptor editing" for self-reactivity, occur in the bone marrow and peripheral lymphoid organs.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Antigen-Specific Receptors: Both B cells and T cells develop antigen-specific receptors. B cells produce a membrane-bound form of antibody as their antigen-specific receptor, while T cells develop T-cell receptors (TCRs).

 

Option B: Class I MHC Expression: Both B cells and T cells express Class I MHC molecules. These are present on nearly all nucleated cells in the body and are important for presenting endogenous antigens to CD8+ cytotoxic T cells.

 

Option D: All of the Above: Since only positive selection is unique to T cells, this option is not correct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Positive selection during development, which ensures that T cells have T-cell receptors capable of recognizing self-MHC molecules, occurs in T cells but not in B cells. Understanding the unique and shared aspects of T and B cell development is important for recognizing how different immune deficiencies can affect the immune system's function.

 

(Ref: Immunology by SK Gupta 1st/142-150, Robbins 10th 194-6, 216)

choices.text: Increased turnover of extracellular matrix proteoglycans
Increased growth of capillary endothelial cells

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a painless lesion on her ear lobe (shown in the image) after getting her ears pierced 3 months ago. Which of the following best explains the pathogenesis of this lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Maturation arrest of collagen assembly
 

Option D:

 

Keloid is a scar that tends to progress beyond the site of initial injury and recurs after excision. Dark-skinned persons are more frequently affected by keloids than light-skinned people. Keloids are characterized by changes in the ratio of type III to type I collagen, suggesting a maturation arrest in the healing process.

 

This is the hallmark of keloid formation. In keloids, there is an overproduction of collagen type I which is unable to reorganise itself into a proper scar. This results in a thickened and raised scar that grows beyond the boundary of the original wound.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. While extracellular matrix components, including proteoglycans, play a role in wound healing, their turnover is not the primary defect in keloid formation.

 

Option B. Granulation tissue is the new connective tissue and microscopic blood vessels that form on the surfaces of a wound during the healing process. Exuberant granulation tissue can lead to hypertrophic scars, which are similar to keloids but do not grow beyond the boundaries of the original wound.

 

Option C. This process is more related to the formation of granulation tissue during wound healing. Although it is an essential part of the healing process, it does not specifically lead to keloids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In keloids, there is an imbalance in the synthesis and degradation of collagen, with an increase in the ratio of type I to type III collagen. This suggests a failure in the normal maturation process of collagen during wound healing, leading to the excessive scar formation typical of keloids.

 

Ref: https://journals.lww.com/prsgo/fulltext/2013/07000/keloids_and_hypertrophic_scars__update_and_future.5.aspx

questions.text: A middle-aged male presents with a painless, slow-growing swelling in the neck. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is performed. For which of the following thyroid cancers is FNAC least likely to provide a definitive diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Follicular thyroid cancer

Option B:

FNAC cannot be useful for making a diagnosis of follicular thyroid cancer as it cannot distinguish between benign and malignant thyroid tumors.

FNAC cannot reliably distinguish between benign and malignant follicular neoplasms because the diagnosis of follicular thyroid cancer requires evidence of vascular or capsular invasion, which cannot be assessed on aspiration cytology.

Explanation:

Option A. FNAC is highly effective for diagnosing papillary thyroid cancer due to characteristic cytological features such as nuclear grooves and pseudoinclusions.

Option C. FNAC can suggest a diagnosis of medullary thyroid cancer by demonstrating amyloid and calcitonin-rich cells; however, serum calcitonin levels and genetic testing are also important for diagnosis.

Option D. FNAC can often suggest anaplastic thyroid cancer due to the presence of highly atypical cells and necrotic material; however, the aggressive nature of the disease often requires rapid additional diagnostic and therapeutic interventions.

Educational Objective:

FNAC has limitations in diagnosing follicular thyroid cancer because it requires histological evidence of capsular or vascular invasion to differentiate between benign and malignant lesions, which cannot be determined by cytology alone.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents with persistent cervical dysplasia on Pap smear. Further investigation reveals infection with high-risk HPV. Molecular analysis indicates the presence of a viral protein that interferes with the tumor suppressor Rb gene, promoting cell cycle progression. Which of the following protein produced by HPV suppresses Rb gene?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) E7

Option B:

The E7 protein of HPV binds to and leads to the degradation of the Rb tumor suppressor protein, allowing for the progression of the cell cycle and potentially leading to carcinogenesis.

Explanation:

Option A. The E6 protein of HPV is involved in the degradation of the p53 tumor suppressor protein, not the Rb protein. p53 is another critical regulator of the cell cycle and apoptosis.

Option C. LMP1 is an oncogenic protein associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), not HPV. It is involved in the development of various lymphomas and nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

Option D. Tax is a protein associated with Human T-cell lymphotropic virus type 1 (HTLV-1), not HPV. It plays a role in the development of adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma (ATLL).

Educational Objective:

E6 promotes the degradation of p53, and E7 inactivates the Rb protein, disrupting normal cell cycle control and contributing to the risk of cervical cancer development.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/324

choices.text: EGFR positive in non small cell cancer
Her 2 amplification is seen in most breast cancer
N myc  is a tumor suppressor gene

questions.text: In the context of tumor biology, which of the following statements is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) EGFR positive in non small cell cancer

 

Option B:

EGFR positivity is commonly seen in non-small cell lung cancer, particularly adenocarcinoma subtype, and can be a target for specific therapies.

Explanation:

Option A.  BRCA1 is not an oncogene but a tumor suppressor gene. Mutations in BRCA1 are associated with an increased risk of breast and ovarian cancers.

Option C. Her2 amplification occurs in some breast cancer cases but is not seen in the majority. It is significant because Her2 status can affect treatment options and prognosis.

Option D. N myc is a proto-oncogene, not a tumor suppressor gene. It can become an oncogene when mutated or overexpressed, as seen in some cases of neuroblastoma.

Educational Objective:

BRCA1 is a tumor suppressor gene, EGFR can be overexpressed in non-small cell lung cancer, Her2 is amplified in a subset of breast cancers, and N myc is a proto-oncogene associated with certain types of cancer (neuroblastoma).

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/285, 292

questions.text: A patient presents with a growth suspected to be related to a low risk HPV subtypes.  Which of the following is most likely responsible with HPV strains 6 and 11?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Laryngeal papillomatosis

Option C:

Laryngeal papillomatosis is caused by low-risk HPV strains, such as HPV-6 and HPV-11, which generally lead to benign conditions like warts and respiratory papillomatosis.

Explanation:

Option A. Cervical carcinoma is typically caused by high-risk HPV strains such as HPV-16 and HPV-18, not the low-risk strains that cause laryngeal papillomatosis.

Option B. Oral carcinoma can also be caused by high-risk HPV strains, particularly HPV-16, which is associated with oropharyngeal cancers.

Option D. Anorectal carcinoma is associated with high-risk HPV strains, similar to cervical and oral carcinomas.

Educational Objective:

Low-risk HPV strains, such as HPV-6 and HPV-11, are associated with benign conditions such as laryngeal papillomatosis, while high-risk HPV strains are associated with malignancies like cervical, oral, and anorectal carcinoma.

choices.text: Activation of cell signaling pathways

questions.text: 45-year-old woman is diagnosed with breast cancer, and her tumor cells demonstrate overexpression of the HER2/neu proto-oncogene. What is the primary mechanism by which HER2/neu contributes to the pathophysiology of her cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Activation of cell signaling pathways

Option D:

Proto-oncogene HER2/neu encodes for a protein that is a receptor for growth factors. Its over-expression can lead to excessive activation of downstream cell signaling pathways, including the PI3K/Akt and MAPK/Erk pathways, which promote cell proliferation and survival. HER2/neu overexpression is associated with a more aggressive breast cancer phenotype and poorer prognosis.

HER2/neu is a receptor tyrosine kinase that, when overexpressed, results in the excessive activation of downstream signaling pathways, including PI3K/Akt and MAPK/Erk, that are known to promote cell proliferation and survival.

Explanation:

Option A.  Inhibition of cell proliferation is not associated with HER2/neu overexpression; instead, HER2/neu leads to increased cell proliferation.

Option B. Promotion of apoptosis is not a mechanism of HER2/neu action. In contrast, HER2/neu overexpression tends to confer resistance to apoptotic signals.

Option C. While HER2/neu overexpression can have downstream effects that might indirectly promote angiogenesis, this is not the primary action of the proto-oncogene.

Educational Objective:

Overexpression of the HER2/neu proto-oncogene in breast cancer leads to the activation of cell signaling pathways that promote cell proliferation and survival. This overexpression is associated with a more aggressive disease phenotype and a poorer prognosis. Targeted therapies against HER2/neu can be effective in treating tumors with this over-expression.
